Maoist regime in China is responsible for a large number of deaths during its rule, particularly during the Great Leap Forward campaign (1958-1962) and the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976).

During the Great Leap Forward campaign, Maoist policies led to a massive famine that caused the deaths of an estimated 15 to 45 million people. The famine was caused by a combination of factors, including forced collectivization, the Great Sparrow Campaign (which aimed to eradicate sparrows, seen as pests, leading to an increase in insect populations and crop damage), and the diversion of resources from agriculture to industry.

During the Cultural Revolution, Mao encouraged a mass movement of Chinese citizens to root out "counter-revolutionary" elements within society. This led to the persecution, torture, and execution of millions of people, including intellectuals, artists, and other "bourgeois" elements. Violence was also carried out by Red Guards, groups of young people who were mobilized to enforce Mao's ideology and often carried out violent attacks on individuals and institutions perceived as counter-revolutionary.

Overall, Maoist policies and actions resulted in the deaths of an estimated 40 to 70 million people in China.

Nelson Mandela was a prominent anti-apartheid activist and politician in South Africa who was imprisoned for 27 years. During his imprisonment, Mandela was subjected to various forms of torture and mistreatment, including being forced to do hard labor, being placed in solitary confinement for long periods of time, and being denied access to medical treatment.

Mandela and his fellow prisoners were also subject to psychological torture, such as being denied access to newspapers, books, and radios, and being prohibited from speaking to each other for long periods of time. They were also subjected to harsh interrogations and physical abuse, including beatings and electric shocks.

Despite the torture and mistreatment, Mandela remained committed to his cause and emerged from prison as a symbol of resistance against the apartheid regime. After his release, he played a key role in negotiating an end to apartheid and became the first black president of South Africa in 1994.
